story.text: (Updates to late morning)TOKYO Jan 4 (Reuters) - The Nikkei average rose 0.84 percent on Thursday, the first trading day of 2007, with Toyota Motor Corp. (7203.T) rising on news that it became one of the Big Three automakers in 2006 and other exporters advanced on a softer yen. Tokyo markets are open for a half day of business on Thursday from 09:00-11:00 a.m. (0000 GMT-0200 GMT). They were closed Monday through Wednesday for New Year's holidays. "The Nikkei is up following solid growth in U.S. and European markets during our market holidays," said Tsuyoshi Segawa, an equity strategist at Shinko Securities. "The fact that the yen has been getting softer since the end of last year and that market participants tend to focus on hopeful stocks for the year, Toyota and Nippon Steel for example, is also helping the rise." The Nikkei was up 144.56 points at 17,370.39 as of 0107 GMT. The broader TOPIX index .TOPX gained 1.18 percent to 1,700.90. Segawa said gains may be limited into next week, however, as investors are concerned that stocks might have risen too far. Shares of Toyota rose 2 percent at 8,120 yen following data showing its sales rose more than 16 percent in the United States in December, ousting DaimlerChrysler DCXGn.DE to become one of the Big Three automakers in 2006. Toyota's stock earlier hit a record high of 8,140 yen. Investors were also encouraged to buy Toyota and other automakers with the dollar trading near a 12-week high versus the yen. Honda Motor Co. (7267.T) gained 1.3 percent at 4,760 yen and Nissan Motor Co. (7201.T) added 2.1 percent at 1,463 yen. A weaker yen is a boon to Japanese exporters as it boosts profits when earnings from abroad are brought home. The U.S. dollar was trading at 119.27 against the yen JPY= in early Asian trading. NTT DoCoMo Inc. was up 2.7 percent to 193,000 yen after the Nikkei business daily said Japan's largest mobile operator will keep initial investment on its so-called super 3G network down to 100-200 billion yen, which may enable DoCoMo to cut down fees and help retain users.
